awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Rapid Detection of Fecal Contamination in Drinking Water
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project concerns a novel, rapid and cost
effective detection system for fecal contamination in water supplies. Although existing methods can
detect fecal contamination in water samples, improvements are needed in sensitivity, accuracy, and speed.
This proposal describes the refinement of a novel sensor utilizing an insect chemosensory protein as the
recognition element in a product that detects indole, a characteristic metabolite of coliform bacteria. The
biosensor acts with high specificity and sensitivity, allowing the rapid detection of low level E. coli or
fecal contamination in water supplies, and encompasses a novel implementation of lateral flow
technology that can be used at home or in industry.
The broader impacts of this research are that insect CSP-based biosensors as described constitute a
platform technology with direct applications in the detection of environmental, chemical, or biological
compounds or contaminants, including the detection of harmful volatile organic compounds (VOCs),
quality control of foods and pharmaceuticals, the detection of toxins or stereoisomers generated during
chemical or pharmaceutical synthesis, and the detection of volatile compounds present in weapons or
explosives. These biosensors can also be used in medical diagnostics as well as numerous other
applications where high speed, sensitivity and analyte selectivity are required. The platform technology
has immediate application to a variety of important sensor and detector implementations that affect
numerous industries, public safety, and public health. The water safety monitor described herein is only
one example of the applications possible.

por.por_cntn:
Maintaining a safe, clean supply of potable water is crucial to public health because water-borne microbes are responsible for numerous diseases in humans. For example, Escherichia coli (E. coli) and other bacteria, collectively known as coliform bacteria, can enter the water supply due to fecal contamination and can result in digestive distress, severe illness, and even death. Children, the infirm, and the elderly are particularly at risk, and waterborne disease claims over 1 million lives annually around the world. E. coli is used as a general indicator of fecal contamination in water supplies, but the current testing methods are not quick enough to always protect the public. For example, current methods approved by the US Environmental Protection Agency for testing water safety require roughly 1 day to generate a result.

This project has focused on the development of a novel, rapid and cost effective detection system for fecal contamination in water supplies. The research strategy resulted in a novel biosensor utilizing an insect chemosensory protein as the recognition element in a product that detects indole, a characteristic metabolite of coliform bacteria. The biosensor acts with high specificity and sensitivity, allowing the rapid detection of low level E. coli or fecal contamination in water supplies, and encompasses a novel implementation of lateral flow technology with domestic and industrial applications.

 The broader impact of this research is that biosensors utilizing insect chemosensory proteins as detector elements constitute a new platform technology. This new technology has direct applications in the detection of environmental, biological, and chemical compounds, pollutants, or contaminants. For example, the technology is applicable to the detection of harmful volatile organic compounds (VOCs), toxins or stereoisomers generated during chemical or pharmaceutical synthesis, and volatile compounds present in weapons or explosives. Furthermore, the technology is applicable to quality control processes for food and pharmaceutical production, in medical diagnostics, as well as numerous other applications where high speed, sensitivity and analyte selectivity are required.

Therefore, the results and technologies generated by this project have immediate application to a variety of important sensor and detector implementations that affect numerous industries, public safety, and public health.  The water safety monitor described herein is only one example of the applications possible.
